label: Letter 2 from Sidney Jennings Legendre, August 7, 1943
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Legendre, describing his day spent playing tennis with friends and his social activities on the island.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Original
copy sent to American
Embassy
32
August 7, 1943
Dear Gertie,
It is Sunday night and a lovely day has passed
that you would have enjoyed. In the morning I arose at seven th
irty, cooked breakfast and lounged around the aprtment until
ten thirty. Then I stro led over to the Outrigger club and
sun bathed and swam alternatelingly until one thirty when I
had lunch. It was so lovely lo king at the blue sea, the
white breakers, the dark b dies of the men skimming over the
sunlit w ter, and the distant horizon curving from
Diamond head away out to sea and then back again to the mountains
in the north. After lunch Morris who had stayed in bed
all morning an I went out house hunting, but with no success alth 
ough I have found out a certain amount about property values ,
the cost of land etc. Believe me it is high, like Palm Beach.
I suppose that people do not want to sell because they are not
s re what they can do with the money. Afterwards we played 
tennis doubles with Sargeant Kahnamoku, and a boy called
Crowley. It was not much fun as they did not play well and
it was difficult to have a rally. Sargeant Dukes brother,is
very n ce b t has not the charm that Duke has. After dinner of
soup at six thirty I lay down on my bed and read part of the
Forest and the Fort by Hervey Allen. There were such
wonderful word picutres of Autumn in the Indian country that
I longed to see the smoke curl up slowly from the fires ,
smell it in the air, see the big crimson leaves float down and
have th t lovely country of valleys and rivers lie before me.
Do you remember how l vely it was even in spots around Ithaca,
and on the ride down from Amsterdam one fall we sa w such
vivd coloring that I have always remembered it. The b ck itself
is not marvellous, apparently it is to be the first one of a
series of six on the Indi n wars, a history of the early days
in this country.
The radio brought the bad news that we are all quaranti
in the Waikii distrcit. I will be allowed to go back and forth
to work but that is all. On return from work I have to go
straight to my apartment and stay there until I le ve to go
morning for work again. There is n epidemic of Dengue fever
and the army and navy has slapped this order on this district.
I am sorry that swimming and tennis etc. stop at revelry
tomorrow morning for an indefinite length of time. Morris that
lucky stiff is leaving on a ship tomorrow morning and will
probably miss it all by the time he gets back. Ah well c'est
la guerre. It will probably mean that I will stay at the
office longer and do more work so th t is all to the good,
because I ill being giving more to my goverment than I have
in the past.
[End Page 1]
Your letter from the river club, written late at night,
was received and I felt so sorry for you because you were
lonely and tired. I could tell by the letter what the tro ble
was. You were over tired and did not real ze it. You do not
realize how much Washington has taken out of you, and then a
week end at Pollys is not the most restful thing that I know 
of. My advise is th t you go up to Watch Hill and stay there with
the children for two weeks and not do anything but lie on the
beach, eat andppull Honeys ears. At first you will probably
think you are going mad because you want to do something os
much, then after a while you will suddenly feel very tired and
sleep all the time, after this you will beggin to feel your
self again. I am only suggesting this as I know you will
not do it,
Your discription of meeting the old general is delightful.
Could anyth ng be stupider than having to go on a British ship.
Of course if they send you on a portugese one I believe you
automaticaly receive the Navy Cross and the army distinguid
service medal for just agreeing to go. If the cockroaches do not
carry away a leg the fleas will. Personally I would rahter take
my chances in the old Washington office
Last night we went to the movie at the royal Hawaiian
and saw Betty Grable in "Coney Island". The sail rs love her a
and whistle and shout whenever she moves. They sometimes make
very funny remarks that are earthy and to the point. This
picutre ia alabout a beer hall on Coney that Grable is singing
at. A man ith great showmanship takes hold of her and tried
to te ch her how to sing with ut jumping over the stage l ke
a rabbit. He is unable to until he puts handcuffs on her
legs and arms and the plants her in one spot just before the
curtain goes up. Unable to spring about like an antelope she
sings and of course brings the house down, and lau ches on a
famous career where you are shown a shower of newspaper
headings with her name head lined. It is down in the appro ed
hollywood manny and thought the story is not marvellous
the use of tecn icolor is edcellent and gives some wonderful
effects especially in a song which she sings rom a river boat.
Did you have Rose stop the flowers from Sm lls or
have them sent to the children in Watch Hills. If not the person
who rented the house from you will be slightly surprised to receive
flowers xxxxxxxx one a week without any warning. Also if you
see the priceless R se ag in tell her to be sure and store out
golf clubs lying down as otherwise they will all be bent li e
bows when the war is over. When I come back I do not want to
live in one place right away.. I want to go to Maine, Forida,
Virginia, come out to Honolulu, see Austalia and New Zealans
etc. I don't particulay want to go to Europe I have seen that
so many times, that there is li tle int rest there compared to
the pl ces we h ve not seen.
Goodbye dea, I send you all my love.
Sidney J Legendre
[End Page 2]
